ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I received a basic overview of domestic and foreign policies of countries in the MENA region, and learned how to defend their policies.

Insights into the history, state formation, demographics etc. of Middle Eastern countries as well as their foreign policies and relationships to other countries in the area. Focusing on how those policies and relationships have changed over the last several decades.

I learned about the foreign policies of each country in the Middle East from their perspective, which is really valuable because we are often taught the US foreign policy objectives toward the Middle East. I also gained insights into international relations and regional politics beyond the state, how a region is impacted by global politics. Overall, I learned how to view and understand Middle Eastern countries interests and interactions with other countries in the region and beyond.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: strengths: the professor was extremely adaptable, and would lead the class discussion according to our interests. weaknesses: none, I thoroughly enjoyed this course.

I think it's a wonderful course and the professor adapted it to our small class by allowing us to take more personal responsibility for the material we were learning and present/defend it to each other. The readings were excellent and the discussions were a good balance of student thoughts/questions and the professor's knowledge. It's a shame that it will not be taught next year because I think the main thing that would improve the course would just be to have a few more students in it.

It was the ideal class I would have wanted: focused on student learning rather on doing useless work for the sake of work. The readings were succinct and made sense why we had to read them. Class discussions were a perfect balance between the Professor framing the readings and the students discussing.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes. This course gave me a great overview of the domestic and foreign policies of many states in the MENA region. The course had the perfect balance between class discussions and professor lectures. I felt fully engaged the entire time, learned a lot, and had fun as a student enrolled in it.

Absolutely yes, I think the material is very interesting, very important, and very little understood even among students who study (for example) polisci or IR at Yale. The professor is wonderful (very knowledgeable, easy to talk to, kind and accommodating). At first I was intimidated by the length of the readings but they're all very interesting so it was not a burden.
Yes, definitely if you want to learn about the Middle East from a less Euro-centric and American-centric perspective.
